structure.unit: COUNTIES, CITIES, AND OTHER LOCAL UNITS
COUNTY GOVERNMENT (FISCAL COURTS AND COUNTY COMMISSIONERS)

law.catch_line: Petition to form commission to study adoption of charter county form of government or consolidation of agencies and services.

text.section: A petition authorized pursuant to KRS 67.830(2) shall meet the requirements of this section. The petition shall be drafted in such a way that the effect of signing the petition is to support the formation of a commission to study the question of the adoption of a charter county form of government or the consolidation of any agency, subdivision, department, or subdistrict providing any services or performing any function for a city or a county.

Any five (5) qualified voters within the unincorporated area of the county or five (5) qualified voters within the most populous city within the county may commence petition proceedings by filing with the county clerk an affidavit stating they constitute the petition committee and will be responsible for circulating the petition and filing it in proper form. The affidavit shall:
State the names and addresses of the committee members;
Specify the address to which all notices to the committee are to be sent; and
Set out in full the proposal to be considered by the voters.

No later than fourteen (14) business days after the affidavit of the petition committee is filed, the county clerk shall:
Notify the petition committee of all statutory requirements for petitions under this section; and
Deliver a copy of the affidavit to the fiscal court and the legislative body of each city within the county.

section.section: Within thirty (30) days after the petition is filed, the county clerk shall complete a certificate as to its sufficiency.

If the county clerk finds the petition sufficient, the clerk shall send a certificate of the petition's sufficiency, by certified mail, to:
The petition committee;
The fiscal court of the county; and
The legislative body of each city within the county.

If the county clerk finds the petition is insufficient, the clerk shall:
File a certificate of insufficiency specifying the particulars making it insufficient; and
Send a copy of the certificate, by certified mail, to:
The petition committee;
The fiscal court of the county; and
The legislative body of each city within the county.

A petition certified insufficient for lack of the required number of valid signatures may be amended once if the petition committee files:
A notice of intention to amend it with the county clerk within five (5) days after receiving the certificate of insufficiency; and
A supplemental petition upon additional sheets within thirty (30) days of receiving the certificate of insufficiency. The supplemental sheets shall comply with all requirements established by subsection (4) of this section.

Within ten (10) days after the supplemental petition is filed, the county clerk shall determine if the amended petition is sufficient. If the county clerk finds the amended petition sufficient, the clerk shall complete a certificate of sufficiency and send a copy of certificate of the petition's sufficiency, by certified mail, to:
The petition committee;
The fiscal court of the county; and
The legislative body of each city within the county.

text.section: A final determination as to the sufficiency of a petition shall be subject to review in the Circuit Court of the county. This review shall be limited to the validity of the county clerk's determination. A final determination of insufficiency shall not prejudice the filing of a new petition for the same purpose in accordance with this section.

law.history: Created 2012 Ky. Acts ch. 63, sec. 1, effective January 1, 2013.
